pr_title: Filtering nulls from joins when possible

timeline.bodyText:
I tried to add this optimisation in PlanOptimizers where all the other optimizers live . ssaumitra@07ca92e
The problem was that, RelationPlanner converts equality join expressions to JoinNode.EquiJoinClause. So IsNotNullPredicate can no longer be constructed over there. If there is a way to make that work, please let me know.
CC. @rschlussel
timeline.author: ssaumitra

replies.bodyText:
Looks good.
When you are at it, also add it to the inner table of an outer join - so right side of left join and left side of right join can use the same optimization
replies.author: kaikalur

replies.bodyText: Makes sense. I will add that.
replies.author: ssaumitra

timeline.message: Filtering nulls from left and right in inner join
Join optimisation: filtering null rows explicitly
Join optimisation: filtering null rows explicitly
Join optimisation: filtering null rows explicitly

timeline.bodyText: Are you sure these are just the keys not any other expressions?
timeline.author: kaikalur

replies.bodyText:
@kaikalur These can be expressions as well, which can be completely resolved from left and right. For example, for the query
SELECT DISTINCT a.orderkey FROM 
(SELECT CASE WHEN orderkey > 10 THEN orderkey END orderkey FROM orders WHERE orderkey < 100) a 
RIGHT OUTER JOIN 
(SELECT * FROM orders WHERE orderkey < 100) b ON a.orderkey = b.orderkey

I am expecting optimised version as
SELECT DISTINCT a.orderkey FROM 
(SELECT CASE WHEN orderkey > 10 THEN orderkey END orderkey FROM orders WHERE orderkey < 100) a 
RIGHT OUTER JOIN 
(SELECT * FROM orders WHERE orderkey < 100) b ON a.orderkey = b.orderkey
WHERE CASE WHEN orderkey > 10 THEN orderkey END IS NOT NULL

Which is okay IMO, because CASE WHEN orderkey > 10 THEN orderkey END IS NOT NULL can get pushed down to scan operator for orders table.
replies.author: ssaumitra

replies.bodyText: This might end up introducing a regression, especially when NULLs are rare and/or expression is expensive. I think a better way to implement this is to do this in plan optimization (add an additional filter node after project to avoid recompute the expression). If nothing else, the default of this flag should be false. Maybe we should run some benchmarking first.
replies.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText:
As discussed offline, we were thinking of doing performance testing. In the meantime, planned CSE changes will solve this problem.
We will roll out this optimisation in disabled state. And when CSE changes are released, we will re-enable this.
replies.author: ssaumitra

timeline.bodyText:
Looks good. Just add one more test with some conditions like:
WHERE a.x IS NULL
etc. so we can ensure that we did not push that down.
timeline.author: kaikalur

replies.bodyText: Added now. It's interesting to see how NULL filtering works in FULL OUTER JOIN.
replies.author: ssaumitra

replies.bodyText: I actually meant WHERE clauses not AND in ON clauses because we should not be pushing those down.
replies.author: kaikalur

replies.bodyText: @kaikalur Sure. My code does not touch Predicate pushdown. So this should not change. Updating test just for completeness.
replies.author: ssaumitra

timeline.author: rongrong
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -61,10 +60,12 @@ public void testNonStraddlingJoinExpression()
         assertPlan("SELECT * FROM orders JOIN lineitem ON orders.orderkey = lineitem.orderkey AND cast(lineitem.linenumber AS varchar) = '2'",
                 anyTree(
                         join(INNER, ImmutableList.of(equiJoinClause("ORDERS_OK", "LINEITEM_OK")),
-                                any(
-                                        tableScan("orders", ImmutableMap.of("ORDERS_OK", "orderkey"))),
                                 anyTree(
-                                        filter("cast('2' as varchar) = cast(LINEITEM_LINENUMBER as varchar)",
+                                    filter("ORDERS_OK IS NOT NULL",

timeline.bodyText: Why is the null filter added to complexJoinExpressions rather than leftComparisonExpressions or rightComparisonExpressions?
timeline.author: rongrong
